summary:
A 1-hour, 60-mark Maths paper with a clear progression from quick core skills to multi-step applications and number reasoning. The style is traditional and syllabus-led (no calculator, show working), with a few distinctive reasoning items: defining special number types, prime factorisation of a composite, a custom operation, and an LCM/intervals question requiring justification.

English addendum: An English-only paper split into two equal halves: 25 multiple-choice reading questions (one correct answer each) and one creative-writing continuation task. The reading leans on vocabulary-in-context, precise inference, and identifying writer’s methods (metaphor/personification), while the writing task rewards sentence control (including subordination), accuracy, realism, and controlled figurative language.

topicWeighting.topic: arithmetic fluency (place value, powers/roots, long multiplication, fraction simplification)
fractions, decimals, percentages (incl. fraction of remainder, % to fraction, decimal display)
money calculations (unit prices, change, credit/allowance style)
time and units (time differences, comparing times in mixed formats)
measurement and compound measures (volume, perimeter/area, string around a box)
geometry (angles in triangles, angle facts, reflections on grids, shaded fractions)
number properties and number theory (primes, squares/cubes, Fibonacci/triangular/perfect/powerful, prime factorisation)
structure/reasoning (use given calculation to infer related results, custom operation, LCM/intervals with justification)

formatRules: Paper timing and scoring: 1 hour, total 60 marks; show marks per question/part and keep early questions low-mark, later questions higher-mark.
Instructions must include: answer as many questions as you can; show all working clearly; do not spend too long on one question; calculators not allowed.

Front-loaded “quick answers” section: several short prompts in a row (place value scaling like ×10,000; index notation; square/cube roots; fraction simplification; percentage of a number; multi-digit multiplication).

Include at least one “calculator display” style place-value question where a known decimal display is used to infer a related decimal (e.g., scaling denominator by 100). Online version should simulate a fixed-width 10-digit display box.
Money change problem format: multiple items with different unit prices (pence and pounds) plus a note payment; output is a £ change amount.
Include one symmetry/reflection task on a grid with a vertical mirror line; online version should be click-to-place letters or select mirrored positions (do not require drawing tools).
Fraction-of-what-remains structure: give an amount, take a fraction away, then take a fraction of the remainder; ask for the final remainder (money).
Read values from dual-scale diagrams: thermometer-style scales with °F and °C, then compute a difference in °C. Online diagrams must have clear tick marks and labels.

Time arithmetic appears in two formats: (i) minutes between two clock times with minutes not on the hour, (ii) comparing durations given in hours+minutes, total minutes, and fractional hours; require identifying quickest/slowest (ordering).
Fractions in shapes: shaded fraction of a repeated-tile design (e.g., hexagon tiling) plus ‘how many more tiles to reach 3/4 shaded’; also include a shaded fraction of a larger rectangle diagram.

Percent-to-fraction conversion appears explicitly (e.g., 15% as a simplest fraction). Also include an applied percentage uplift (e.g., +15% free allowance) that changes how long something lasts; require working.

Area and perimeter are diagram-driven: overlapping rectangles (area of the larger-only and total combined covered area) and a rectangle-vs-square equal-perimeter question asking for difference in area; include 'diagram not drawn to scale' where appropriate.
Angle questions are short and fact-based: missing angle in a triangle; a composite angle diagram to find angle a; then classify a given angle as acute/obtuse/reflex.
Right triangle question requires both perimeter and area from given side lengths; keep numbers manageable without a calculator.
3D measure question bundle: volume of a cuboid; then a string-wrapping question with an added fixed bow length (multi-step perimeter-around-faces reasoning).

Number classification set: choose numbers from a given range that meet named properties (prime, square, cube, Fibonacci, triangular, perfect, powerful). Provide short definitions in-question for less common terms (e.g., perfect/powerful).
Short order-of-operations expression with nested brackets appears late as a quick-check item.
Prime factorisation task: express a composite as a product of three primes in increasing order with constraints (a < b < c). Use numbers where factorisation is doable without a calculator.
Use-a-given-product reasoning: provide one multiplication identity and ask for related division and scaled-decimal variants (e.g., 235.7 × 99).
Custom operator question: define a ⟴ b with a specific rule and ask (i) direct evaluation, (ii) nested evaluation, (iii) solve for unknown input producing a given output.
LCM/intervals finale: multiple bells/events ring at given second intervals; ask when they coincide again and require a short justification (LCM reasoning).
UNKNOWN: whether this school also uses any separate multiple-choice paper; this blueprint reflects a single 1-hour written specimen.
maths.difficultyNotes: Moderate-to-hard for 11+: most content is standard, but the paper expects careful diagram reading, confident manipulation of fractions/percentages, and stronger number reasoning (definitions, factorisation, LCM, custom operations). Time pressure is managed by many short items early and a few multi-step reasoning problems later.

topicWeighting.topic: vocabulary in context (meaning from surrounding text)
writer's methods and effects (metaphor, personification, word choice)
purpose/structure of opening (scene-setting, character situation, contrast)
SPaG within writing (subordination, punctuation, grammar, spelling)

formatRules: Total time is 60 minutes. Instructions explicitly suggest spending 30 minutes on each section; both sections carry equal marks.
Section A (Reading): candidates read Passage A and answer 25 multiple-choice questions. Each question has exactly one correct answer. Options are labelled A–D and candidates write the chosen letter.

Reading question style prioritises precision: expect stems like 'What do you think X means in this context?', 'Which statement most accurately describes...', 'Why do you think...', and 'Which phrase best describes the purpose...'.
Include multiple vocabulary-in-context items; distractors should be plausible near-synonyms but wrong for the passage’s specific nuance.
Include at least two items on figurative language identification (e.g., which phrase is a metaphor; classify a phrase as personification).
Include at least one question on authorial purpose/structure (what the first paragraphs achieve: scene-setting, establishing mood, introducing a character situation).
Include at least one 'single word choice' effect question where candidates select which quoted/picked word best conveys an emotion or tone.
Section B (Creative Writing): after reading Passage B, candidates continue the story in a lined space. They do not need to finish the story.

Writing assessment criteria are explicitly stated and should be mirrored: accurate sentences including subordination; correct spelling, punctuation and grammar; realistic narrative; engaging writing with metaphor, simile and personification where appropriate.
The paper instructs students to spend about 5 minutes planning in a box before writing. Online UI should include a planning box plus a main writing area.

Passage A is classic-style descriptive narration with mature vocabulary; Passage B is tense narrative description. For generators, create fresh passages that feel similar in tone and complexity without copying.
UNKNOWN: exact mark breakdown within the reading section (per question) is not given; assume 25 roughly even-weight questions for generation and feedback.
english.difficultyNotes: Reading difficulty comes from close reading and fine distinctions between answer options rather than complex question formats. Writing difficulty is in control: maintaining tone/voice, using subordination correctly, keeping the continuation realistic, and using figurative language naturally within a strict time budget.

commonWrongAnswers: Choosing an option that is broadly true but not the most accurate statement supported by the passage.
Using a dictionary meaning for a word instead of the meaning implied by context.
Confusing metaphor with personification or selecting a vivid phrase that is not the specific device asked for.
Answering inference questions with opinion rather than evidence from the passage.
In writing: shifting tense/voice or losing the tone of the provided excerpt.
In writing: forcing figurative language (overdone similes/metaphors) instead of using a few controlled, relevant images.
In writing: weak sentence control under time pressure (run-ons, comma splices, missing subordination), and basic punctuation slips.
markingAndFeedback.explanationTone: Direct and child-friendly: for reading, point to the exact phrase/idea that makes the correct option best; for writing, give 2–3 concrete improvement targets (one accuracy, one craft) and a short example of a stronger sentence.

generatorHints: Do NOT copy any original questions.
Match the flavour, not the exact content.
Avoid references to printing or PDFs.
Keep questions suitable for an online timed exam.
Keep the exam structure fixed: Section A has 25 multiple-choice questions (A–D, one correct answer), Section B is one narrative-continuation writing task.
Generate two fresh passages: Passage A suited to MCQ comprehension; Passage B as a short narrative excerpt with a clear continuation hook.
Design MCQ distractors to be close and plausible; use 'most accurately' framing for some items.
Ensure the writing prompt explicitly encourages subordination and accurate SPaG, plus restrained metaphor/simile/personification where appropriate, and includes a planning box.
